1090290510886043649.text:
Blockchains depend on P2P protocols. How secure are those? Which trade-offs should protocol designers consider?

@tillneu and Hannes Hartenstein wrote a paper about that. Here is my summary:

Notice: ECDSA signatures where the message isn't a hash and chosen by the "signer" are insecure.

Given public key P, pick random nonzero values a and b. Compute R=aG+bP. Now (R.x, R.x/b) is a valid signature for "message" (R.x*a/b).

1120434143576432641.text:
For fans of type systems, the new rules ILC adds to π-calculus are:
1. Read-ends of channels/tapes are affine (No duplication). Ensures a unique recipient of each message.
2. Singleton write token ⓦ. Spend ⓦ to send, earn ⓦ when you recv. Ensures one active "writer" at a timepic.twitter.com/d5elKEDhpq

1120424852266078208.text:
What does a UC programming language look like? UC is founded on Interactive Turing Machines (ITMs), a fairly obscure computing model. In ITMs, scheduling is deterministic, and only one machine is active at a time.

ILC is π-calculus with a type system to make it behave like ITMs

1120423284372385794.text: As an example, here's an ideal functionality for a commitment scheme in prose, alongside one written in ILC/SaUCy. In the paper we code up the [CF01]  protocol and proof for UC commitments in the trusted-setup model.pic.twitter.com/JW953SWws4

1120421707154640897.text: The payoff is that it's (hopefully) much easier to reason about the Ideal Functionality (simple code for a trusted party), while the actual protocol (with multiple parties, inconsistent views, Bzyantine faults, and cryptography) is much messier.

1120421134648918017.text: UC is already the gold standard for modular composition in cryptography. Each protocol module (π) comes with a proof that it behaves just like its Ideal Functionality (F₂) spec. Devs (ρ) using the module can safely reason about the behavior of F₂.pic.twitter.com/KJ6HBW9QDo

1120405363734601732.text:
Universal Composability (UC) is a unified way to define security properties for Byzantine-secure distributed protocols. Basically you provide code for an idealized trusted third party that behaves just like your protocol. 

(Ideal Functionalities):(Protocols) :: (Mocks):(Objects)pic.twitter.com/maIrHjSmgH

1120403763372732416.text: This project takes one step towards our overall agenda of making Universal Composability a practical tool for modular development of security protocols, such as blockchains, smart contracts, zero knowledge proofs, MPC, and the rest

1070042842716876800.text: So what's the takeaway here? As much fun as it was to write the above, the real discussion is: cryptocurrencies should support network topology measurement natively, without having to resort to clever tricks. Such tricks disproportionately favor attackers rather than helpers.

1070041860951994368.text: Naturally there's more details in the paper, such as how to make this work at scale, how to control for errors, and validation experiments. Credit to @sr_gi as well as @cpsola_ @suryabakshi & others for making this work. As a reward for reading this far, here's a pic of testnet3:pic.twitter.com/dJNyEZODOR

1070040567093055489.text: So, here's the idea: We send a chain of transactions txP-->txM to node A, and then a transaction txF that *double spends txP* to everyone else. Node A forwards txM to its direct peers, who stash it in the orphan buffer without relaying it any further. Voila! (img credit @sr_gi)pic.twitter.com/VUX3AD3nbU

1070038830412193793.text: Anyway, transactions in mapOrphanTransactions can't be checked yet, so they aren't relayed to any other nodes. However, you can probe whether a Tx is in there by sending an INV message about it. If the Tx is in there, it won't ask for it again.

1070038251522658306.text: The first insight is about a little known data structure, mapOrphanTransactions. When a Bitcoin node receives a transaction whose txInputs are unknown, this is where it goes. (Incidentally, years ago I reported a dos vulnerability in mapOrphanTransaction https://www.usenix.org/conference/cset15/workshop-program/presentation/miller … )

1070037364746149889.text: Thrilled to announce TxProbe, the latest in Bitcoin p2p topology inference. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1812.00942.pdf … The goal is to probe whether two reachable nodes are in fact connected directly to each other. Achieving this relies on several subtle insights about how transactions are relayed
